Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Ministernotomy and Standard Sternotomy in Aortic Valve Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: 115 undergoing standard sternotomy and 53 undergoing mini-sternotomy

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were adults requiring only aortic valve surgery, with 115 undergoing standard sternotomy and 53 undergoing mini-sternotomy.

Intervention.evidence: 115 undergoing standard sternotomy and 53 undergoing mini-sternotomy

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare early postoperative outcomes between these surgical approaches.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was early postoperative recovery, assessed by ICU stay and mechanical ventilation duration.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 115 undergoing standard sternotomy and 53 undergoing mini-sternotomy

Number_Analysed.evidence: Data were analyzed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mini-sternotomy group experienced significantly shorter ICU stays (39.92 ± 8.62 hours vs. 55.96 ± 32.56 hours, p < 0.001) and mechanical ventilation durations (5.82 ± 2.44 hours vs. 10.41 ± 14.68 hours, p = 0.030).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were comparable, with no significant differences in perioperative complications.

Trial_Registration.evidence: No trial registration or funding source was reported.

Funding.evidence: No trial registration or funding source was reported.
